Cancer is a phrase for conditions where aberrant cells can infect surrounding tissues and divide uncontrollably. The lymphatic and vascular systems of the body are further routes by which cancer cells might spread. There are various primary cancer kinds:

Carcinoma are cancers that originate in the epithelial cells, which form the lining of organs and glands. The most common types of carcinomas are breast, lung, and colon cancer.

Sarcomas are cancers that originate in the connective tissue, such as bone and muscle

Leukaemia is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow, and lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphatic system.

Lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphatic system, a component of the body’s defence system against pathogens.

Symptoms

Symptoms of cancer can vary depending on the type and stage of the disease. Some common symptoms include

  •   Fatigue
  •   Unexplained weight loss
  •   Pain and changes in the skin

How cancer develops

The building blocks of the human body are cells. When the body requires new cells, existing cells divide and multiply to produce them. Cells typically pass away when they become too old or damaged. New cells then replace the old ones.

Genetic alterations that disrupt this well-ordered process are the cause of cancer. Uncontrollable cell growth starts to occur. A mass of these cells known as a tumour may develop. A tumour may be benign or malignant. Malignant refers to the ability of a cancerous tumour to develop and metastasize to different body regions. If a tumour is benign, it can enlarge but won’t spread.

Some cancers do not produce a tumour. Leukaemia’s, the majority of lymphoma subtypes, and myeloma are some of these.

How the disease spreads

The circulation or lymphatics may transport cancerous cells to other regions of the body as a malignant tumour spread. The cancer cells multiply and may transform into new tumours during this phase. Metastasis is the term for this.

The lymph nodes are frequently one of the initial locations where a malignancy spreads. Small, bean-shaped organs called lymph nodes aid in the battle against infection. They are grouped together in many areas of the body, including the neck, the groin, and the underside of the arms.

Cancer may potentially travel to distant areas of the body through the bloodstream. These components could be the brain, liver, lungs, or bones. The malignancy is still given its original location’s name even if it spreads. For instance, breast cancer that has spread to the lungs is referred to as metastatic breast cancer rather than lung cancer.

Risk factors associated with cancer

Anything that could raise a person’s risk of contracting an illness is a risk factor. Although a risk factor doesn’t always lead to the disease, it can weaken the body’s defences. As potential risk factors and cancer-causing pathways, the following include:

  • Lifestyle elements Smoking, eating a lot of fat, or working with toxic chemicals may increase your risk of adult cancer. Most cancer patients are too young to have experienced these lifestyle risks.
  • Many childhood malignancies may be influenced by genetics, inheritance, and family history. It is conceivable for a family to experience cancer in different forms more than once. 
  •       A few inherited conditions – Our immune system protects us against illness and infection. Bone marrow generates immune cells. One theory is that bone marrow cells have abnormalities that cause them to divide and form malignant or abnormal cells. A genetic defect, toxin, or virus may have caused the stem cell deficit.
  • Encounters with certain viruses – Epstein-Barr virus and HIV increase the risk of paediatric malignancies like lymphoma. Viruses may alter cells similarly. That cell then divides to generate an altered cell, which becomes a malignant cell that divides to make more cancer cells.
  • Exposures to the environment – Pesticides, fertilisers, and electricity have been linked to paediatric cancers. Unrelated children in certain neighbourhoods and cities are contracting cancer. Exposure to these drugs during pregnancy or birth may cause cancer or be a coincidence.
  • A few high-dose radiation and chemotherapy treatments – In certain instances, exposed youngsters may acquire a second cancer later in life. These potent anticancer substances can change immune system components or cells. As a result of the treatment for one cancer, a second malignancy may develop.

Hope Hospital’s cancer clinic treats a wide range of cancer types, includes

  •   Breast cancer – cancer that develops in the cells of the breast
  •   Lung cancer – cancer that starts in the lung, usually in the cells lining the air passages
  •   Prostate cancer – cancer that develops in the prostate, a small gland in the male reproductive system
  •   Colorectal cancer – cancer that starts in the large intestine or the rectum
  •   Melanoma – a type of skin cancer that develops in the cells that produce pigment
  •   Bladder cancer – cancer that starts in the bladder, the organ that stores urine
  •   Non-Hodgkin lymphoma – a type of cancer that starts in the lymphatic system, a network of vessels and glands spread throughout the body. It is characterized by absence of Reed-Sternberg cell.
  •   Hodgkin lymphoma – Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is a type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, which is part of the immune system. It is characterized by the presence of a specific type of abnormal cell called a Reed-Sternberg cell.
  •   Ovarian Cancer – Cancer that begins in the ovaries, two small organs located on either side of the uterus that produce eggs and hormones.
  •   Pancreatic Cancer – Cancer that begins in the pancreas, an organ located behind the stomach that produces hormones and enzymes to aid in digestion.
  •   Thyroid Cancer – Cancer that begins in the thyroid, a butterfly-shaped gland located at the base of the neck that produces hormones that regulate metabolism.
  •   Bone cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the cells of the bone.
  •   Cervical cancer that develops in cervical tissues (the organ connecting the uterus and vagina).
  •   Kidney cancer that begins in the cells of your kidneys.
  •   Gastric cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the lining of the stomach
  •   Oesophageal cancer is a form of cancer that develops in the oesophagus, the muscular tube connecting the mouth and the stomach
  • Gall bladder cancer is a type of cancer that develops in the gallbladder, a small organ located under the liver that stores bile, a fluid that helps digest fats.
  • Oral cancer is a type of cancer that affects the lips, tongue, gums, cheeks, roof of the mouth, and floor of the mouth.
  • Throat cancer also known as pharyngeal cancer, is a type of cancer that affects the pharynx, which is the hollow tube that runs from the back of the nose to the top of the windpipe.
  • Vaginal cancer is a specific kind of cancer that affects the muscular canal that links the uterus to the exterior of the body, the vagina.
  • Ovarian cancer is a type of cancer that affects the ovaries, the female reproductive organs that produce eggs and the hormones oestrogen and progesterone.
  • Pancreatic cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the pancreas, a gland located behind the stomach that plays a role in regulating blood sugar and producing enzymes to aid in digestion.
  • Uterine cancer also known as endometrial cancer, is a type of cancer that affects the lining of the uterus, called the endometrium.
  • Testicular cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the testicles, the male reproductive glands located inside the scrotum.

Hope Hospital’s cancer clinic employs several methods for diagnosing cancer, includes

Biopsy

Your doctor takes a sample of cells during a biopsy to examine in a lab. There are numerous approaches to sample collection. The sort of cancer you have and where it is located will determine which form of biopsy is best for you. Most of the time, a biopsy is required to make a certain cancer diagnosis.

Doctors examine cell samples under a microscope in a laboratory setting. Normal cells have a consistent appearance, similar sizes, and a well-organized layout. Cancer cells appear less organised, with a range of sizes and no discernible organisation.

Lab examinations

Your doctor may employ laboratory testing, such as blood and urine tests, to find anomalies that could be brought on by cancer. For instance, a routine blood test called a complete blood count may detect an unusually high or particular kind of white blood cell in leukaemia patients.

Physical examination

Your doctor might check several parts of your body for lumps that could be cancerous. Your doctor may check for anomalies during a physical examination, such as skin colour changes or organ enlargements that could be signs of cancer.

Imaging studies

Through imaging tests, your doctor can do a less invasive examination of your bones and internal organs. A Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI),  computed tomography (CT) scan, positron emission tomography (PET) bone scan,   ultrasound, and X-ray are a few of the imaging procedures that can be used to diagnose cancer.

Hope Hospital’s cancer clinic offers several treatments for cancer, includes

Bone marrow transplant

A stem cell transplant is another name for a bone marrow transplant. The substance that produces blood cells in your bones is called bone marrow. Your own cells or donor cells may be used in a bone marrow transplant.

Surgery Involves the removal of the tumour and surrounding tissue.

Immunotherapy Cancer is treated using your body’s immune system, which is known as biological treatment. Due to your immune system’s failure to identify it as an outside invader, cancer can thrive unchecked in your body. Your immune system’s ability to “see” and combat cancer can be improved with immunotherapy.

Chemotherapy are drugs used to kill cancer cells.

Hormone therapy

Your body’s hormones can fuel certain cancers. Breast and prostate cancer are a couple such examples. These hormones may prevent the growth of cancer cells if they are removed from the body or their effects are blocked.

Radiation therapy

To kill cancer cells, high-powered energy beams like X-rays and protons are used. When receiving radiation therapy, it may be administered internally or externally (external beam radiation) (brachytherapy).

Targeted drug therapy

Targeted medication therapy focuses on particular cancer cell defects that enable cancer cells to survive.

Stem cell transplant uses healthy stem cells to replace diseased or damaged cells.

It is important to note that cancer treatment is a complex and individualized process, and the best course of treatment will depend on the type and stage of the disease, as well as the overall health of the patient.

What makes Hope Hospital best option for Cancer Clinic

Hope Hospital is a renowned cancer centre known for its cutting-edge treatments and compassionate care. Here are some of the reasons why Hope Hospital is considered the best option for cancer treatment:

Multidisciplinary approach

At Hope Hospital, cancer patients have access to a wide range of specialists, including oncologists, radiation oncologists, surgeons, and pathologists, all working together in a multidisciplinary team. This allows for a comprehensive and personalized approach to cancer treatment, which can result in better outcomes for patients.

Advanced technology

Hope Hospital is equipped with the latest technology and equipment for cancer diagnosis and treatment. This includes state-of-the-art imaging equipment, such as MRI and PET scanners, as well as advanced radiation therapy techniques, such as IMRT and IGRT, which can target and destroy cancer cells with great precision.

Supportive care services

Cancer treatment can be physically and emotionally demanding, and Hope Hospital offers a wide range of supportive care services to help patients cope with the side effects of treatment. This includes physical therapy, nutrition counselling, and psychological support.

Patient-centred care

At Hope Hospital, the patient’s well-being is the top priority. Patients receive care that is tailored to their specific needs and preferences. The hospital also has a patient and family advisory council that offers feedback and suggestions to improve patient’s experience.

Experienced and skilled staff

The medical staff at Hope Hospital is highly experienced and skilled, and they are dedicated to providing the best possible care to their patients. They are also up-to-date with the latest developments in cancer research and treatments, which means they can offer the most advanced and effective care to their patients.

Conclusion

Hope Hospital is a top-rated cancer centre that offers comprehensive and personalized care to cancer patients. With its multidisciplinary approach, advanced technology, clinical trials, supportive care services, cancer survivorship program, patient-centred care, experienced and skilled staff, and community outreach program, Hope Hospital is a top choice for cancer treatment.

What triggers cancer?

Cancer is brought on by two different types of causes. One is a propensity or propensity to have cancer. The other is being exposed to the initiating triggers. Cigarettes, environmental pollutants, UV exposure, or liver damage are a few examples.

 

Pollutants and chemicals: are they cancer-causing?

only in a very tiny number of exceptional circumstances. Long-term exposure to a few substances may result in a few uncommon malignancies in particular occupations. Most of these compounds have been discovered and are now under regulation.

 

Will my hair regrow?

Yes, transient hair loss following chemotherapy. Usually following the conclusion of therapy, it will grow back. In some circumstances, hair can regrow while receiving treatment. For the first year, the hair typically has a different texture. Following that, it often returns to way it was before you received chemotherapy after about a year. Radiation therapy-related hair loss may be permanent.

 

Does smoking actually cause cancer?

Yes. Most lung cancers are brought on by cigarettes. They play a significant role in the development of kidney, mouth, larynx, bladder, pancreatic, and oesophageal cancers.

 

How is cancer handled?

Surgery, radiation, and medications are all options for treating cancer. Most treatments require a combination of treatments, such as surgery along with radiation therapy or medication, etc. Initial testing is carried out to make the diagnosis and ascertain how far the disease has advanced in order to choose the best course of action for a specific patient. This information is used to plan the treatment. It is periodically evaluated how well an illness responds to treatment. In most cases, the treatment must be administered over time. Cancer patients require ongoing monitoring after the intended course of treatment has over.

 

How does radiation operate?

Cancer cells and other dividing cells are destroyed by radiation. Damage is also done to healthy cells. However, today’s powerful robots can precisely remove cancerous cells while sparing healthy tissue.
